"We shall never return to social sanity till we begin at the beginning. We must start where all history starts, with a man and a woman, and a child, and with the province of liberty and property which these need for their full humanity. As it is, we begin where history ends...We judge everything by the muddle of the moment." G.K. Chesterton in Illustrated London News 1919 quoted from Dale Ahlquist's book Common Sense 101.
 
 Do you believe the traditional family is the basic building block of society/civilization? If so, why? If not, why not?
Master_Shake

Do you believe the traditional family is the basic building block of society/civilization? If so, why? If not, why not?

 If what you mean by "traditional family" is a mom, a dad, 2.5 children and a dog, then no.
 This is because how a family is defined depends on the culture and the time you ask the question, not to mention on the individual families themselves.
 
 But to answer your question in a nutshell: I do believe that family is the foundation of society, but I do not believe that family has to be what has come to be known as the "traditional" family in the U.S. at this moment in time.

The "traditional" family is one building block of many building blocks that make up our soceity. Gays have families just like straights. Gay families are also building blocks our of society. Every facet of humankind is in and of itself a building block in society. Everybody contributes to some degree and there is no one that is more important than the other. It takes many diverse "blocks" to build a successful society.

Do you believe the traditional family is the basic building block of society/civilization? If so, why? If not, why not?

 
 I stand behind the other posters who ask for a definition of "traditional families". But since I know what you mean - my answer is a resounding NO. Good people caring for each other are the building blocks of society. That can take many shapes and forms and it is the intent of the people who will make it strong - not the specific construct. I used to be part of two "traditional" families and it they were a living hell. My family is different now - and we love each other and we are strong. 
 
 Your sanctamonious Hallmark card sentimentality towards the "traditional" family leaves out, insults, slights, and trivializes a lot of people - not just those families that include homosexuals.
jyoshu

I believe we have to be very careful when trying to say one form of family is somehow superior to any other. There are always going to be cases where a non-status-quo families do a better job than what's considered the status quo by some. 
 
 When it's all said and done, I think showing love toward children, caring for them, and nurturing them is what makes a good family.

 Welcome Mrs. Ketcham, glad to make your acquaintance.
 
 Just thought I'd add to your comment, as you started to make a very good point.
 
 The fact that homosexuals can't marry makes comparing them to married heterosexual couples a bit like comparing Apples to Bicycle tires. 
 Not to mention the fact that whatever crazy stats he may be attempting to quote is bit of fact that not all homosexuals are "out" so making up such a statistic is quite far fetched. 
 There's simply no way to know how many homosexual couples actually do outlast his erroneous percentage. 
 Just as census information shows that homosexuals WHO RESPONDED to census questionnaires only make up about 2 - 3% of the total population, making a GUESSTIMATE of the actual number of homosexuals is highly politicized. 
 
 I just thought I'd through that in, just to keep things on an even keel.

Allow me to welcome you, too, Mrs. K.
 
 As to this fear of homosexuals these people have (at least in fora like this), I think the "latent traits thingy" has more to do with it than you think, and the God thingy is just a convenient justification--especially that the latter is so full of contradiction and depends to such an extent on removal from context and arbitrary verse interpretation. Not that they're all  complete closet cases--most people are at some mid-range of the continuum, and are either comfortable with it to some degree or not--but I think their rating on the Kinsey probably increases in direct proportion to the amount of time and energy they devote to posting messages on Gay Rights internet boards. I mean, if they can't tell us -- even when repeatedly asked -- what actual, real-world impact the topic has on their own lives, then it logically stands to reason that that impact is something they don't want to admit to. And, gee, what do you think that could that be? 
 
 Not exactly rocket science.
 
 Again, welcome to the forum and I look forward to your future posts.
